I'm currently using my HyperNEAT library with Boost 1.34 so I'm sure
it's s=
upported, as long as you made the appropriate changes to the
makefile (whic=
h you obviously did).

It sounds like the system can't find the boost libra=
ry.  This is
either because you didn't install the boost library to a syste=
m path,
or because there isn't a copy of the library in the same directory =
as
the executable.

In linux, there's an environment variable called LD_LIB=
RARY_PATH which
you can set to find extra libraries.  It should work for OS=
/X too.

Here's something you can try:

1) Copy the boost threading library=
 to the directory of the HyperNEAT
executable.

2) Run this:  LD_LIBRARY_PA=
TH=3D"./" ./Hypercube_NEAT


P.S. If you dig up a better way to use the boo=
st threading libraries
with cmake, please let me know.  Thanks!

Jason G.

=

Hey Jeff,
> > 
> > I haven't tried to build the library with OS/X yet.
> > =

> > It looks like you are having trouble getting the boost libraries
> > l=
inked in.
> > 
> > The problem is that the boost library has this complex n=
aming
> > convention for its libraries and it is hard to write a script tha=
t can
> > handle every possible case.  I believe that the creators of cmake=
 are
> > working on a script which is comprehensive enough to work on all
s=
ystems.
> > 
> > In the meantime, here is what you can do:
> > 
> > 1) Get =
the boost library (either by building yourself or using a
binary)
> > 
> > =
2) Find out what library name the boost threading examples use.
> > 
> > 3)=
 edit the CMakelists.txt inside the Hypercube_NEAT directory and in
> > the=
 TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(...) section, replace the boost thread
> > library n=
ame with the appropriate name.
> > 
> > 
> >
